no pii in name: Please take care not to name your assessment with any identifiable information. (e.g. Individual or Organization Names)
asset gross value: What is the gross value of the asset you are trying to protect?
expected effort: What is the relative expected effort for this assessment?
no search results: No items were found matching the search request.
to start an assessment: To start a new assessment, click on a card.  To view additional details click the {icon} icon.
account already exists: An account already exists for the email address
email not allowed: The specified email is not allowed by this installation
control priorities intro1: Each unanswered question or question answered with a “No” response is ranked by priority below. Organizations can use this information to pinpoint specific areas where additional resources or mitigating controls may be necessary to achieve compliance. Questions are ranked in order of highest priority to lowest.
control priorities intro2: The following factors are used to determine the priority of each question/requirement:
control priorities bullet1: The specific weighting value assigned to each question.
control priorities bullet2: The weighting value of the subject area or question category.
control priorities bullet3: The security assurance level of the question.
control priorities bullet4: The component criticality value assigned by the user, if applicable.
control priorities intro3: Questions and categories were analyzed and assigned a weight relative to others within the assessment.
link version: Click here to view or download releases.

disclaimer.title: Disclaimer
disclaimer.disclaimer 1: The analysis, data, and reports in {{appShortName}}® are provided “as is” for informational purposes only. The {{orgLongName}} ({{orgShortName}}) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. In no event shall the United States Government or its contractors or subcontractors be liable for any damages, including but not limited to, direct, indirect, special, or consequential damages and including damages based on any negligence of the United States Government or its contractors or subcontractors, arising out of, resulting from, or in any way connected with this report, whether based on warranty, contract, tort, or otherwise, whether injury was sustained from, or arose out of the results of, or reliance upon the report.
disclaimer.disclaimer 2: {{orgShortName}} does not endorse any commercial product or service, including the subject of the assessment or evaluation in this report. Any reference to specific commercial products, processes, or services by trademark, manufacturer, or otherwise, does not constitute or imply its endorsement, recommendation, or favoring by {{orgShortName}}.
disclaimer.disclaimer 3: The display of the {{orgShortName}} official seal or other {{orgShortName}} visual identities on this report shall not be interpreted to provide the recipient organization authorization to use the official seal, insignia or other visual identities of {{orgShortName}}. The {{orgShortName}} seal, insignia, or other visual identities shall not be used in any manner to imply endorsement of any commercial product or activity by {{orgShortName}} or the United States Government. Use of the {{orgShortName}} seal without proper authorization violates federal law (e.g., 18 U.S.C. §§ 506, 701, 1017), and is against {{orgShortName}} policies governing usage of the seal.
disclaimer.disclaimer 4: The report is prepared and intended for internal use by the organization that made the request. The contents of this report may be subject to government or private intellectual property rights. To request distribution of this report outside the organization for which it was prepared, contact {{intellectualPropertyRightsDistributionRequestEntity}}. The contents of this report may be reproduced or incorporated into other reports, but may not be modified without the prior express written permission of the {{appShortName}} Program Office.

advisory.title: Advisory
advisory.advisory 1: The {{appLongName}} ({{appShortName}}®) is only one component of the overall cybersecurity picture and should be complemented with a robust cyber security program within the organization. A self-assessment with {{appShortName}}® cannot reveal all types of security weaknesses, and should not be the sole means of determining an organization's security posture.
advisory.advisory 2: The tool will not provide a detailed architectural analysis of the network or a detailed network hardware/software configuration review. It is not a risk analysis tool so it will not generate a complex risk assessment. {{appShortName}}® is not intended as a substitute for in‑depth analysis of control system vulnerabilities as performed by trained professionals. Periodic onsite reviews and inspections must still be conducted using a holistic approach including facility walk-downs, interviews, and observation and examination of facility practices. Consideration should also be given to additional steps including scanning, penetration testing, and exercises on surrogate, training, or non-production systems, or systems where failures, unexpected faults, or other unexpected results will not compromise production or safety.
advisory.advisory 3: {{appShortName}}® assessments cannot be completed effectively by any one individual. A cross-functional team consisting of representatives from operational, maintenance, information technology, business, and security areas is essential. The representatives must be subject matter experts with significant expertise in their respective areas. No one individual has the span of responsibility or knowledge to effectively answer all the questions.
advisory.advisory 4: Data and reports generated by the tool should be managed securely and marked, stored, and distributed in a manner appropriate to their sensitivity.

connection.details 1: The server cannot be reached.  Please contact a system administrator to verify that the server URL is properly configured and that the CSET API is running.

sal.sal intro1: The Security Assurance Level or SAL determines the number of questions to be answered and the level of rigor of the assessment.
sal.sal intro2: For example, a typical high SAL will contain 350-1000 questions where a low SAL will typically contain 30-350 questions, depending on the selected standard.
sal.sal intro3: The SAL applies to Standard and Diagram Component question sets.
sal.choose methodology: Choose one of the three SAL methodologies below to determine the correct level for your assessment.
sal.confidentiality text: This value relates to the importance of protecting information from unauthorized access. The more important it is that unauthorized users do not have access to the information the higher your SAL level.
sal.integrity text: This value relates to the the importance of the accuracy of information. The more important it is that information is kept consistent, accurate, and only changed by those authorized the higher your SAL level.
sal.availability text: This value relates to the importance of information being readily available. The more important it is to have your information available for use the higher your SAL level.

gen sal.text1: Answer the following questions to help determine the SAL for your assessment by selecting the potential impacts on people and/or economic factors in the event your system is compromised.
gen sal.injuries desc: If control systems were maliciously accessed and manipulated to cause harm, how many people could sustain injuries not requiring hospital stay in a worst-case scenario? (Consider injuries caused due to any reason.)
gen sal.hospitalizations desc: If control systems were maliciously accessed and manipulated to cause harm, how many people could sustain injuries requiring hospital stay in a worst-case scenario? (Consider injuries caused due to any reason.)
gen sal.deaths desc: If control systems are maliciously accessed and manipulated to cause harm, how many people could be killed in a worst-case scenario? (Consider injuries caused due to any reason.)
gen sal.capital loss desc: For a worst-case scenario, estimate the potential cost of losing capital assets or the overall economic impact. (Consider the cost of site buildings, facilities, equipment, etc.)
gen sal.economic impact desc: For a worst-case scenario, estimate the potential cost in terms of economic impact to both the site and surrounding communities. (Consider any losses to community structures and use and any costs associated with displacement.)
gen sal.environmental desc: For a worst-case scenario, estimate the potential cost of environmental cleanup to the site and surrounding communities. (Consider the cost for cleanup, fines, litigation, long-term monitoring, etc.)

nist.fips guide text: The FIPS 199 guide below will help you learn how to determine the overall security categorization of the system under assessment. If you are unfamiliar with the FIPS 199 SAL Determination screen, please read the guide before proceeding.

level.evolving-desc: limited complexity in terms of the technology it uses.
level.intermediate-desc: uses technology that may be somewhat complex in terms of volume and sophistication.
level.advanced-desc: uses complex technology in terms of scope and sophistication.
level.innovative-desc: uses extremely complex technology to deliver myriad products and services.

irp.irp desc end: across five categories. It is measured on a scale from least risk to most risk in this order below:

irp.overall risk level has been overriden to: Overall Risk Level has been overriden to

level selection.para 1: Select the level appropriate to your organization's assessment.
level selection.l1 a: Foundational. Level 1 is comprised of the 15 basic safeguarding requirements specified in Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) Clause 52.204-21. Level 1 is achievable by self-assessment.
level selection.l2 a: Advanced. Consists of 110 practices aligned with NIST SP 800-171. Requires annual self-assessment for select contractors or triennial third-party assessments for critical national security projects. The advanced level will calculate a scorecard with the Supplier Performance Risk System (SPRS) score.
level selection.l2 b: Level 2 can be used for a self-assessment or a certification assessment. It incorporates the security requirements specified in NIST SP 800-171 Revision 2.
level selection.l3 a: Expert.  Consists of selected security requirements derived from National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Special Publication (SP) 800-172.
level selection.l3 b: Level 3 only applies to systems that have already achieved a Final Level 2 (C3PAO) CMMC Status.

scoring.score charts description 1: The following chart(s) illustrate the organization's progress in meeting the cybersecurity standards evaluated in the CMMC assessment. This page provides data based on the level selected on the CMMC Target Level Selection page (e.g., if the user selects a target level of 2, charts for both Level 1 and Level 2 will display). This approach ensures clarity and focus on the immediate requirements.
scoring.score charts description 2: Scoring within the CMMC program is cumulative, meaning organizations must achieve compliance in all previous levels before advancing to the next one. For instance, an organization must complete the requirements for Level 1 and Level 2 before progressing to Level 3.
scoring.score charts description 3: For further guidance, refer to the CMMC Tutorial within the Prepare section. A link to CMMC documentation is also available in the Additional Resources section.
scoring.inactive description 2: Please note that Level 2 is not enabled, as the organization has not met the compliance requirements for Level 1.
scoring.inactive description 3: Please note that Level 3 is not enabled, as the organization has not met the compliance requirements for Level 2.
scoring.scorecard description: The table below lists all practices and their corresponding responses, organized by level and then by the individual domain. Additionally, if a requirement is not met, the points deducted from the total score are shown in the Deduction column.
scoring.perf by domain desc: The following chart shows the percentage of practices Met or N/A for each domain at target level {{targetLevel}}.
scoring.perf by level desc: The following chart(s) displays the percentage distribution of each response type by level.

core.include above target: Include questions above maturity target level

htag.does not apply: The following accessibility features does not apply to our software

p.1: In consideration of Section 508 of the U.S. Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. 794d), the features and functions in this application have been developed to support users with accessibility requirements. Industry best practices and standards have guided our design and development processes to incorporate accessibility features built into the Windows operating system and the .NET architecture, as well as the Chrome, Firefox, and Edge browsers. The software development team is committed to integrating accessible design thinking throughout the entire product development cycle. More information on Section 508 and the technical standards can be found at www.section508.gov.
p.2: Many of the documents in this application are in HTML or ASCII (plain text) formats. These formats are generally accessible to people who use screen readers. We also have a large number of documents in Adobe Acrobat® Portable Document Format (PDF). When using a screen reader to read documents directly in PDF format using Adobe Acrobat Reader, you will likely need to install an accessibility plug-in. This plug-in is available free of charge on the Adobe Accessibility website.
p.3: Our team works to integrate Section 508 accessibility considerations in every application update and release.
p.4: We offer app-specific keyboard shortcuts in the Help menu.
p.5:
We recommend the use of Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and Mozilla Firefox for optimal application functionality. For accessibility functionality specific to each browser, please visit the following features lists:
  • Google Chrome Accessibility Features
  • Microsoft Edge Accessibility Features
  • Mozilla Firefox Accessibility Features
p.6: We believe that a trusted, effective, open-source cybersecurity tool should be readily available and accessible to all.
p.7: To ensure the most accessible experience for all of our users, in addition to the above Section 508 best practices, we regularly test our software for the following functionality:
p.8: We test that all functionality can be accessed and executed using only the keyboard.
p.9: We check to ensure that labels and instructions are provided for each form input and that each form label is sufficiently descriptive. We test the page to check that notifications are provided of each form-related change in content. We expect any errors to be identified in text and sufficiently described to the user, with additional guidance (e.g., suggestion for corrected input) provided about how to correct errors for form fields. Finally, our web page allows our user to check, reverse, and/or confirm submission.
p.10: We test that each link and button can be determined from any combination of the link/button text, accessible name, accessible description, and/or programmatically determined context. We also check that the page provides notification of each change in content that is the result of interaction with a link or button.
p.11: We check the relative order of repeated components so they match with other pages.
p.12: We test for functionality that each heading describes the topic or purpose of its content, and that each programmatically determinable heading is a visual heading. We want each visual heading to be programmatically determinable. We check for programmatic heading levels to logically match the visual heading presentation within the heading structure, so that all visually apparent lists are programmatically identified according to their type.
p.13: We check that the default human language of each Web page can be programmatically determined, and that any passage (content, image descriptions, form labels etc.) that differs from the default language of the page is identified correctly.
p.14: We test to identify that a title element is defined for the web page, and that it identifies the contents or purpose of our page.
p.15:
We test to ensure that:
  • Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element
  • The visual presentation of text and images of text have sufficient contrast
  • The text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 & Large-scale text and images has ratio of at least 3:1
  • Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on sensory characteristics of components, such as shape, size, visual location, orientation, or sound
p.16: The accessible name and description for a meaningful image provides an equivalent description of the image.
p.17: We check for functionality to resize, scale, or zoom in on the text to at least 200% of its original size without loss of content or performance.
p.18: We work to make sure our users find information is available using more than one way to locate the web page so they can find information quickly.
p.19: We test that when an error is detected, an alert is displayed with text describing the error
p.20: This accessibility feature does not apply to our software.
p.21: We check that data tables’ row or column headers are identified programmatically, data cells are associated with relevant headers, and that the layout table does not include structural attributes.
p.22: We check that interactive interface elements with multiple statuses indicate a current status, and that an input form role reflects its function accurately so any input text fields will have the correct value.
p.23:
• Autoplay/update
  • Flashing
  • Adjustable time limits
  • Video-Audio only
  • Multimedia
  • Time Outs
  • Required Plug-ins
  • Alternative Version

change password.ransomware explanation: Ransomware is an ever-evolving form of malware designed to encrypt files on a device, rendering any files and the systems that rely on them unusable. Malicious actors then demand ransom in exchange for decryption. These resources are designed to help individuals and organizations prevent attacks that can severely impact business processes and leave organizations without the data they need to operate and deliver mission-critical services.

about.learn more: To learn more about cyber vulnerabilities, training, standards, and references, visit the CISA Vulnerability Management website or contact {{dhsEmail}}.
about.encourage reporting: CISA — Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency — encourages you to report suspicious cyber activity, incidents, and vulnerabilities affecting critical infrastructure control systems.
about.training available: Training is available through the following resources
about.training description: The training program events consist of Web-Based Training courses, 'regional' training courses and workshops at venues in various locations, in addition to the 5-day training event held in Idaho Falls, Idaho.
about.training no cost: Note: All training courses are presented at no cost to the attendee.
about.aes training description: The Assessment Evaluation and Standardization (AES) Program qualifies individuals to conduct Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) cyber assessments.
about.aes link: Assessment Evaluation and Standardization Program - CISA

parameters.text1: Many Standards in 'Requirements Mode' contain parameters that you can change to match your specific situation. The table below allows you to change the parameter values for the indicated parameter names in this Assessment by clicking on the Parameter Value. Changing a parameter value will update all related parameter values in the requirement text of the currently selected Cybersecurity Standard(s).
parameters.text2: Parameters can also be customized by clicking on them in the control text. Note that changes made at that level are scoped to the specific control.
parameters.none: The selected cybersecurity standards do not contain any customizable control parameters.
parameters.dialog prompt: Define the value for the selected control parameter.

login.login prompt: Enter your email address and password to login
login.origin: The Cyber Security Evaluation Tool (CSET®) is a Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) product that assists organizations in protecting their key national cyber assets. It was developed under the direction of CISA by cybersecurity experts. This tool provides users with a systematic and repeatable approach for assessing the security posture of their cyber systems and networks. It includes both high-level and detailed questions related to all industrial control and IT systems.

Questions present in both the old and newer versions will be transferred, along with their observations, attached documents, feedback, and comments. Additionally, all demographic information and contacts will be transferred. Your original assessment will remain accessible, and this upgrade will generate a new assessment.

compare.sal comparison: Overall Comparison of Security Assurance Levels
compare.both need diagrams: Comparison visuals are available only when both assessments include network diagrams.
compare.percentages may not equal 100: Percentages may not add up to 100% when comparing assessments due to averaging answers.
compare.compliance 1: Answer distributions are viewable on the 'Best To Worst' tab.
compare.para 1: This graph summarizes the overall compliance percentage for the selected assessments. In addition, it breaks down compliance by standard questions and component questions. If the assessments do not contain component questions, the Overall percentage will match the Standards percentage. Compliance is determined by the number of questions answered "Yes," "Alt," or "Implemented" out of the total number of questions, excluding those marked as "N/A."
compare.para 2: When comparing the same assessment type across different business units, this graph helps identify the organization's overall compliance. Alternatively, when comparing different assessment types for a specific area or critical service, it highlights the areas or service's overall compliance.
compare.para 3: This chart compares the overall compliance percentages of each of the selected assessments. In addition, it breaks down compliance by standard questions and component questions.
compare.para 4: Based on the selected assessments, the graph can offer insight into the organization’s progress in meeting the cybersecurity standards evaluated in the assessments over time or by area/service.
compare.para 5: This comparison shows the Security Assurance Levels (SALs) for each of the selected assessments, as determined on the SAL page within the Prepare section of the assessment.
compare.para 6: This comparison shows the compliance percentage for each of the selected assessments across all categories. If analyzing a single organization across time, this helps the user determine the organization’s progress in each category. If comparing two different business units, it helps identify each department's strengths and highlights areas for improvement. In addition, it illustrates how each business unit performs relative to one another. The selected assessments are labeled with the user-defined aliases specified on the Comparison Details page.
compare.para 7: This chart displays the percentage distribution of each response type for standard-based questions across all selected assessments. The percentages may not add up to 100% due to the averaging of answers.
compare.para 8: This chart displays the percentage distribution of each response type for component-based questions across all selected assessments. The percentages may not add up to 100% due to the averaging of answers.
compare.para 9: This graph summarizes the average compliance percentages for all selected assessments across each individual category. When comparing the same assessment type for various business units, it helps identify the organization’s overall compliance for each category. Alternatively, when comparing multiple assessment types for a specific area or critical service, it highlights the overall compliance for that area or service in each category. This allows organizations to pinpoint where they excel in meeting cybersecurity standards and where improvements are needed.
compare.para 10: This table presents the total count of each response type, categorized by the selected assessments. The selected assessments are labeled with the user-defined aliases specified on the Comparison Details page.
compare.para 11: This table lists questions or requirements that were left unanswered or received a “No” or “Not” response in all selected assessments. Organizations can use this information to pinpoint specific areas where additional resources or mitigating controls may be necessary to achieve compliance.
compare.para 12: These charts present the percentage distribution of each response type for the selected assessments, listed in descending order from most compliant to least compliant (i.e., the assessment with the highest number of “Yes,” Alt,” or “Implemented” responses appear at the top.)
compare.para 13: Use the side navigation to view additional charts for those categories. The selected assessments are labeled with the user-defined aliases specified on the Comparison Details page.
compare.para 14: Select each tab to view additional charts and graphs illustrating the comparison results. The Overall Summary tab is available only for comparisons involving standard-based assessments. The charts within the Individual Assessment Comparisons tab vary depending on whether the comparison is between standard-based assessments or maturity models.
compare.para 15: This page includes a variety of graphs that help the user identify any trends among the selected assessments. The Trend function is only applicable to standard-based assessments.
compare.para 16: This graph illustrates the overall compliance percentage for the selected assessments over time. In addition, it breaks down compliance by standard questions and component questions. If the assessments do not contain component questions, the Overall percentages will match those of the Standards percentages.
compare.para 17: This graph provides insight into the organization's progress toward meeting the cybersecurity standards evaluated in the assessments. Compliance is determined by the number of questions answered "Yes," "Alt," or "Implemented" out of the total number of questions, excluding those marked as "N/A."
compare.para 18: This graph highlights the top five categories, within the selected assessments, that have most improved over time. Organizations can use this data to track and communicate their performance and measure the impact of implementing mitigating controls.
compare.para 19: In contrast to the previous graph, this graph highlights the top five categories, within the selected assessments, that have shown the least improvement over time. Organizations can use this information to identify where to allocate additional resources and implement effective mitigating controls.
compare.para 20: This comparison shows the compliance percentage for each of the selected assessments across all categories. If analyzing a single organization across time, this helps the user determine the organization's progress in each category. If comparing two different business units, it helps identify each department's strengths and highlights areas for improvement. In addition, it illustrates how each business unit performs relative to one another. The selected assessments are labeled with the user-defined aliases specified on the Trend Details page.

compare.question: Question
compare.no missed questions: There are no questions that were answered 'No' on all the compared assessments.

analytics.title: Assessment Analytics
analytics.description 1: This chart displays the implementation scoring of the current assessment in relation to other assessments of the same type, as applicable. Each category is scored, with the minimum, maximum, and median scores charted to illustrate how the current assessment compares to other assessments. Users can choose to view results within the same sector or across all sectors.
analytics.description 2: If additional assessments of the same type have not been conducted, the chart will only display the current assessment results.
analytics.tooltip: Select a sector from Demographics in Assessment Information
analytics.vertical bar: Vertical bar is average score for sample

ModuleContentLaunchComponent p1: This report illustrates the structure and question content of a CSET module, e.g., an industry standard or maturity or best practices model.
ModuleContentLaunchComponent p2: The generated report has controls to show or hide the guidance and References for each question.
